name: Spline-Driven Urban Authoring System
oneLiner: Designer-authored road spline system that encodes spatial intent—such as width, orientation, and intersections—and drives coherent urban layout behavior in real time.
bulletpoints: Built a custom road Blueprint using spline components as the primary authoring interface for urban layout.
Exposed spline-level parameters (road width, orientation, tags) to encode designer intent rather than static geometry.
Implemented spline mesh and virtual texture projection to integrate roads with terrain and suppress landscape grass along road paths.
Designed spline intersection handling to resolve crossings and corners automatically without manual cleanup.
Encoded directionality at the spline level, enabling downstream systems to reason about orientation-sensitive placement.

deepDive.problem: Urban layout tools often treat roads as static geometry, making it difficult for designers to express intent such as spacing, orientation, and hierarchy in a way that downstream systems can reliably interpret.
approach: Designed road splines as the authoritative source of layout intent, exposing semantic parameters rather than relying on baked geometry.
Integrated spline meshes and virtual texture projection so roads interact correctly with terrain, foliage, and landscape systems.
Ensured spline data could be consumed by other systems at runtime, enabling coherent reactions to designer edits without manual iteration.
